entry.et: Middle English clok, from Middle Dutch clocke bell, clock, from Old French or Medieval Latin; Old French dialect (Picard) cloque bell, from Medieval Latin clocca, of Celtic origin; akin to Middle Irish clocc bell

def.dt: :a device other than a watch for indicating or measuring time commonly by means of hands moving on a dialect
:any periodic system by which time is measured
:a registering device usually with a dialect
:odometer
:time clock
:a synchronizing device (as in a computer) that produces pulses at regular intervals
:biological clock
:with or within a time constraint working against the clock
:with clocked speed rather than the order of finish as the criterion for placement trial races against the clock
:continuously for 24 hours :day and night without cessation
:without relaxation and heedless of time
:to use up as much as possible of the playing time remaining in a game (as football) while retaining possession of the ball or puck especially to protect a lead
:to time with a stopwatch or by an electric timing device
:to be timed at
:to register on a mechanical recording device wind velocities were clocked at 80 miles per hour
:to hit hard
:attain realize usually used with up just clocked up a million … paperback sales Punch
:to travel (a distance) over time clocks more than 15,000 miles a year on business
:put in 3 clocking long hours at the office
:to have a specified duration or speed used with in the movie clocked in at just under 3 hours
:to have a specified measure or value used with in the meal clocked in at about $15
:to register on a time sheet or time clock :punch used with in, out, on, off he clocked in late
:an ornamental figure on the ankle or side of a stocking or sock
:a combination clock and radio device in which the clock can be set to turn on the radio at a designated time
:a person (as a worker or student) who keeps close watch on the passage of time
:a clock that can be set to sound an alarm at a desired time
:being in effect, continuing, or lasting 24 hours a day :constant around–the–clock surveillance
:a precision clock that depends for its operation on an electrical oscillator regulated by the natural vibration frequencies of an atomic system (as a beam of cesium atoms)
:a pendulum clock whose shape suggests a banjo
:an inherent timing mechanism in a living system that is inferred to exist in order to explain the timing or periodicity of various behaviors and physiological states and processes
